Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research and Development Project. School Structure and Science Success: Organization and Leadership Influences On Student Achievement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The School Organization and Science Achievement (SOSA) Project will document factors explaining variations in science achievement across schools enrolling ethnically and linguistically diverse students. The research question is: what leadership and organizational features at the school level are associated with mitigating science achievement gaps? Previous school effectiveness studies demonstrate school leadership and social capital influencing student achievement; the SOSA project is unique with its focus on science achievement. Researchers at the University of Connecticut and the University of South Florida St. Petersburg, in collaboration with school districts in their respective states, will identify school leadership practices that can be connected with reductions in achievement gaps related to student ethnicity, English fluency, and social status. At the conclusion of the five-year project, the findings will take the form of recommendations about leadership practices and school organization that can be implemented in other school settings.

The project uses a mixed methods design by combining statistical modeling and qualitative data. Multiple regression analyses highlight those schools populated by fifth graders that have greater or lesser achievement gaps in science. Using social capital theory (i.e., school norms, communication channels, and trustworthiness) comparisons of positive and negative outlier schools will be made via interviews of building principals, classroom teachers and community representatives. The expectation is that schools providing more equitable science experiences to all students will exhibit stronger social capital compared to buildings with disparities in science test scores across demographic categories. These insights will be supplemented by multilevel structural equation modeling to determine the strength of association between various school climate measures (e.g., teacher-to-principal trust, correspondence between teacher and principal perceptions of leadership, and school/community ties) and science achievement as measured by statewide fifth grade science tests. In addition, growth analyses will be used to detect shifts over time and provide insights about the links between policy changes or leadership adjustments, inasmuch as science achievement gaps are affected.

By working with 150 schools in two states, this collaborative research project is designed to generate findings applicable in other school systems. Particularly in settings where science achievement gaps are large, and especially when such gaps vary between schools even when the student populations are similar, the findings from this study will have practical leadership implications. Expertise in this project includes science education, educational leadership, and statistical modeling. This complementary combination increases the depth of the project's efforts along with expanding its potential impacts. Key questions addressed by this project include: to what extent is leadership in science similar to or different from leadership in other subject areas? how do variations in leadership design (e.g., top-down versus distributed leadership) contribute to reductions in science achievement gaps? to what degree can effective leadership mitigate other factors that exacerbate the challenges of providing high quality science learning experiences for every child? Findings will be disseminated via the SOSA Project website, along with leadership development strategies. Deliverables include templates to replicate the study, case studies for professional development, and strategies for supporting the development of science teacher-leaders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to identify systems-level factors that might explain long-standing achievement gaps in science. School effectiveness researchers have documented features of schools’ organizational structures and leadership practices associated with improved and equitable academic outcomes. Funding for this project allowed a careful investigation for similar patterns within elementary schools and their science performance. As proposed, this project applied mixed methods with a combination of quantitative and qualitative data sources.

The first phase of the study was identifying schools that were exceeding expectations in science performance. Because Connecticut exhibits considerable residential segregation and associated variation in school funding, our first challenge was to establish an approach that accounted for student demographics. The goal was to equalize the known differences (e.g., percent of low income students) to determine the extent to which a given school was performing as expected. Using multiple regression, the project could identify schools’ science performance on the Grade 5 Science Mastery Test that showed how far the actual results departed from expectations. Sometimes referred to as “beating the odds” this statistical approach revealed great variability in science outcomes within school districts. In other words, even with similar student demographic profiles, there was a wide range in science outcomes suggesting that schoolwide features were contributing to schoolwide science performance.

With a mechanism for equalizing differences across all 500 schools in the state, the next step was to develop an instrument to capture the organizational and leadership features of each building. Ultimately, the project created a School Infrastructure Survey that was administered to all teachers within a school. It was found that teachers’ views about their school sorted into 8 distinct factors:

Collaborative Teacher Learning in Science

Families as Educational Partners

Principal Dependability

Principal’s Advocacy for Equity

Shared Decision-Making

Supports for Science Teaching

Teacher Pride & Orderly Environment

Trustworthiness of Other Teachers

 

When comparing the eight factors to demographically adjusted test results, all factors except for Trustworthiness of Other Teachers were significantly correlated to schoolwide science outcomes. The reason Teacher Trustworthiness did not correlate was because the scores on this factor was exceedingly high and did not vary across schools. Otherwise, one could predict a school’s science outcomes by measuring the other 7 organizational and leadership factors -- with Families as Educational Partners proving to have the strongest correlation.

Qualitative data were collected to expand upon the survey results. Because qualitative data collection at the school level is labor and time intensive, it is more challenging to express definitive patterns. Nevertheless, interviews with school administrators and teacher-leaders verified that strong emphases on the seven factors helped explain the variability in schoolwide science outcomes. These efforts produced several robust interview protocols that were used with fidelity across a range of schools. The project also employed social network analyses to chart the advice-seeking behaviors of teachers within participating schools. Those results supported the proposition that schools with science performance considered equitable and excellent are also sites with more centralized social networks. Advice seeking in higher performing schools appeared to focus on a small number of key leaders – the principal as well as others who may not hold formal leadership titles. 

We referred to this endeavor as Project SOSA: School Organization and Science Achievement and there is convincing evidence that for schools to realize the goals of reduced educational inequities necessitates to attending schoolwide factors which in turn appears to be sustained by the capacity to employ systems-perspectives about science education. In a state with exceptional disparities in student STEM outcomes, this project offers an important shift in possibilities. Rather than relying on curriculum and instructional interventions to resolve educational inequities, Project SOSA has demonstrated that leadership and organization are key factors. What remains uncertain are the conditions that contribute to stronger leadership and more dynamic organization of elementary schools. While there are strong correlations, important work still remains to understand how to affect those changes. These preliminary findings have great potential implications for raising the quality of science education in K-12 education. Specifically, this project has shown that variability in science outcome equity, especially in relation to family income and student ethnicity, has the potential for being resolved through the intentional influence of organizational and leadership factors at the school level.

This study took advantage of existing conditions within one state. In effect this was a natural experiment that considered school organization and leadership in situ. The reasonable next steps would be to leverage the study’s findings to develop interventions to support and advance school science programs from a systems view. Research tools were developed during this project that could be used to chart the longitudinal influences of organizational and leadership reforms. Further work is required to create programs supportive of school administrators’ science leadership. Similarly, establishing pathways by which teachers serve as science teacher-leaders becomes another vital next step.
